children.value: This exercise aims to compare different Runge-Kutta (RK) methods in terms of numerical accuracy and convergence when solving a first-order ordinary differential equation (ODE).

children.html: y′(t)=−y(t),y(0)=1\begin{aligned} y′(t)=−y(t), \\ y(0)=1 \end{aligned}y′(t)=−y(t),y(0)=1​
y(t)=e−ty(t)=e^{−t}y(t)=e−t

children.value: The numerical methods to be compared are:
We compute the approximate values and errors at each time step

children.html: k1​=f(tn​,yn​),k2​=f(tn​+h/2,yn​+hk1​/2),yn+1​=yn+hk2​\begin{aligned} k_1​=f(t_n​,y_n​), \\ k_2​=f(t_n​ +h/2,y_n​+h k_1​/2), \\ y_{n+1}​=y_n+h k_2​ \end{aligned}k1​​=f(tn​​,yn​​),k2​​=f(tn​​+h/2,yn​​+hk1​​/2),yn+1​​=yn​+hk2​​​

k1​=f(tn​,yn​),k2​=f(tn​+h/2,yn​+hk1​/2),k3​=f(tn​+h/2,yn​+hk2​/2),k4​=f(tn​+h,yn​+hk3​),yn+1​=yn​+6/h​(k1​+2k2​+2k3​+k4)\begin{aligned} k_1​=f(t_n​,y_n​), \\ k_2​=f(t_n​+h/2,y_n​+h k_1​/2), \\ k_3​=f(t_n​+h/2,y_n​+h k_2​/2), \\ k_4​=f(t_n​ + h,y_n​+h k_3​), \\ y_{n+1}​=y_n​+6/h​(k_1​+2 k_2​+2 k_3​+k_4) \end{aligned}k1​​=f(tn​​,yn​​),k2​​=f(tn​​+h/2,yn​​+hk1​​/2),k3​​=f(tn​​+h/2,yn​​+hk2​​/2),k4​​=f(tn​​+h,yn​​+hk3​​),yn+1​​=yn​​+6/h​(k1​​+2k2​​+2k3​​+k4​)​

children.value: Caracteristics: fourth-order convergence, explicit, higher accuracy than RK2.
Uses two nodes (s=2) in a high-order implicit integration formula
Each step requires solving a nonlinear system (fixed-point iteration or Newton iteration)
Characteristics: A-stable, second-order accuracy, implicit computation.
Suitable for stiff ODEs, A-stable and second-order accurate
Step requires solving a nonlinear system.
Number of steps 𝑁 = 10 (step size ℎ=0.1)
RK2 exhibits larger errors, deviating noticeably from the exact solution.
RK4 has very small errors, demonstrating clear advantage of fourth-order convergence.
Gauss-Legendre 2-stage and Radau IIA 2-stage have very small errors, comparable to RK4, and are A-stable implicit methods.
Reducing step size decreases the errors of RK4, GL2, and Radau2 rapidly, while RK2 decreases more slowly.
RK2 has limited accuracy, suitable for non-stiff ODEs with low precision requirements.
RK4 is fourth-order accurate, computationally efficient, and suitable for general non-stiff problems.
Gauss-Legendre and Radau IIA are more stable for stiff problems (A-stable).
Accuracy is comparable to RK4, and larger step sizes can be used without divergence.
For non-stiff ODEs with high accuracy requirements, RK4 is the simplest and most effective choice.
For stiff ODEs or when larger step sizes are desired, implicit methods (Gauss-Legendre / Radau IIA) are more appropriate.
